flow.descriptionCdata:
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.021ce3a0-030c-46bc-9f50-b95ca8fd18ad.description=
This operation iterates through a list of values. It is not recommended to modify the value of the "list" and "separator" inputs during the iteration process.

Inputs\:
    list - The list to iterate through.
    separator - A delimiter separating the list elements.
Default value\: ‘,’ (comma) 

Results\:
    resultString - The current list element (if the response is "has more").

Responses\:
    has more - Another value was found in the list and it has been returned.
    no more - The iterator has gone through the entire list. This response is returned once per list iteration.  A subsequent call to the List iterator operation restarts the list iteration process.
    failure - The operation completed unsuccessfully.

Note\:
   The position of the iterator in the list is tracked by each step's unique identifier. Therefore, you can simultaneously iterate through the same list from multiple steps.
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.0a4a468b-8303-4cae-980d-75b7d162770e.description=This workflow updates the Process Instance State using PEM API. Inputs\: _PROCESS_INSTANCE_ID - Process Instance Id _processInstanceState - Process Instance State (Use value from selection list CSA-ProcessInstance-State) Result\: _processInstanceState -Updated Process Instance State 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.1b9add67-aedf-46ae-bf00-296720016717.description=This workflow updates the Process Instance State using PEM API. Inputs\: _PROCESS_INSTANCE_ID - Process Instance Id _processInstanceState - Process Instance State (Use value from selection list CSA-ProcessInstance-State) Result\: _processInstanceState -Updated Process Instance State 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.204c2671-ea9b-49f3-8d67-21a347970160.description=This workflow returns the component properties and values using Artifact APIs. result\: propertyNameValuesList\: pipe separated list of property name and values ( where each property name and values would be ; seprated and multiple values would be , seprated) e.g. - property 1; value1,value2|property 2; value3|property 3; value3,value4|........ 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.3c04d720-0bc9-42ed-9983-140040683e7a.description=
Check to see if the value stored in a specified flow variable, denoted by key, is null.

Inputs\:
keyName - The key to check, i.e. the name of the flow variable.

Returns\: 
The value in the specified key, i.e. flow variable.

Responses\:
isNull - If the key is a null pointer, i.e. the flow variable doesn't have an assigned value.
notNull - If some value is stored in the key, i.e the flow variable has a value assigned.
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.3e62cd00-8b1e-4219-85b7-ba95a7ed75bf.description=
Runs a SQL command against an Oracle database using the information in the tnsnames.ora file.  

Inputs\:
    TNSPath- The path to the folder of the TNS file tnsnames.ora. This path must be accessible by the OO RAS service. For example, if the RAS and the Oracle server are installed on the same Windows system, the TNSPath might look like “C\:\app\Administrator\product\11.1.0\db_1\network\admin”. If the RAS and the Oracle server are on different Windows systems, you can copy the tnsnames.ora file to the RAS system, then the TNSPath might look like “C\:\Program Files\Hewlett-Packard\Operations Orchestration\RAS\Java\Default\webapp\conf” or “C\:\Temp” depending on where you place the .ora file. 
    TNSEntry - The entry name in the tnsnames.ora file that contains the connection information. The value for this input is case insensitive. For example, the value for the TNSEntry input is “TestEntry”  if the content in the tnsnames.ora file looks like the following\: 

TestEntry \=
  (DESCRIPTION \=
   (ADDRESS \= (PROTOCOL \= TCP)(HOST \= 16.110.111.111)(PORT \= 1521))
   (CONNECT_DATA \=
     (SERVER \= DEDICATED)
     (SERVICE_NAME \= orcl)
   )
 )

    Username - The username to connect to the Oracle database. 
    Password - The password for the Username.
    Command - The command to execute. 
    timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution.
Default values\: 0 

Results\:
    returnResult - Specifies whether the command executed successfully. 
    outputText - The output of the command execution. 
    updateCount - The update count of the command executed.

Responses\:
    success - The command executed successfully.
    failure - Failed to execute the command.

Notes\:
1. This operation only supports Oracle.
2. It is possible to run PL/SQL procedures using this operation. The examples below show the syntax to use for a PL/SQL script\:

BEGIN
  send_message(addressee\=>'b@hp.com',sender\=>'pas@hp.com',subject\=>'Test',message\=>'Test');
END;

Example 1\: BEGIN send_message(addressee\=>'b@hp.com',sender\=>'pas@hp.com',subject\=>'Test',message\=>'Test');END;

Example 2\: BEGIN send_message('b@hp.com','pas@hp.com','Test','Test');END;

Example 3\: {CALL send_message(addressee\=>'b@hp.com',sender\=>'pas@hp.com',subject\=>'Test',message\=>'Test')}

Example 4\: {CALL send_message('b@hp.com','pas@hp.com','Test','Test')}
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.57bf594e-f181-4575-826c-ec8cfc63c37b.description=This workflow updates the Process Instance State using PEM API. Inputs\: _PROCESS_INSTANCE_ID - Process Instance Id _processInstanceState - Process Instance State (Use value from selection list CSA-ProcessInstance-State) Result\: _processInstanceState -Updated Process Instance State 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.6dd2f541-9e01-46c7-8863-9f0614b4a1b2.description=Generic flow to send an e-mail 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.7026fcc4-9402-4b49-90eb-d72ab7feb4ae.description=
Runs a SQL query against an Oracle database, using the information in the tnsnames.ora file.  
The first row is returned on the first run of the operation. Subsequent calls with the same information return the other rows.

Inputs\:
    TNSPath -The path to the folder of the TNS file tnsnames.ora. This path must be accessible by the OO RAS service. For example, if the RAS and the Oracle server are installed on the same Windows system, the TNSPath might look like “C\:\app\Administrator\product\11.1.0\db_1\network\admin”. If the RAS and the Oracle server are on different Windows systems, you can copy the tnsnames.ora file  to the RAS system. The TNSPath might look like “C\:\Program Files\Hewlett-Packard\Operations Orchestration\RAS\Java\Default\webapp\conf” or “C\:\Temp” depending on where you place the .ora file. 
    TNSEntry - The entry name in the tnsnames.ora file that contains the connection information. For example, the value for the TNSEntry input is “TestEntry” if the content in the tnsnames.ora file looks like the following\: 

TestEntry \=
  (DESCRIPTION \=
   (ADDRESS \= (PROTOCOL \= TCP)(HOST \= 16.110.111.111)(PORT \= 1521))
   (CONNECT_DATA \=
     (SERVER \= DEDICATED)
     (SERVICE_NAME \= orcl)
   )
 )

    Username - The username to connect to the Oracle database. 
    Password - The password for the Username.
    Command - The command to execute. 
    Delimiter – The delimiter to use between the columns in the returnResult result.
    Key – The key to use to keep multiple query results distinct.
    timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution.
Default values\: 0 

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Returned the data returned for each row separated by the value you specified in the Delimiter input (for example, “key16|lst|16”).
    columnNames - The names of the columns returned, separated by the value you specified in the Delimiter input (for example, “MYKEY|NAME|ID”).
    rowsLeft - The number of rows remaining that match the query. 

Responses\:
    more items - More rows are available for retrieval.
    no more items - No more rows are available.
    failure - There was an error executing the command.

Notes\:
1. This operation only supports Oracle. 
2. This operation can only execute the "SELECT" statement. For statements that modify the database, use the TNS Names SQL Command operation.
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.75bf24c9-1528-456a-81a7-d6bb7a88ebf2.description=Generic flow to send an e-mail 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.934c7b93-86a9-48d2-a378-8cde364bfbf0.description=This workflow updates the Process Instance State using PEM API. Inputs\: _PROCESS_INSTANCE_ID - Process Instance Id _processInstanceState - Process Instance State (Use value from selection list CSA-ProcessInstance-State) Result\: _processInstanceState -Updated Process Instance State 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.c06267c6-b6b6-4279-935a-febe19d94db2.description=This workflow updates the Process Instance State using PEM API. Inputs\: _PROCESS_INSTANCE_ID - Process Instance Id _processInstanceState - Process Instance State (Use value from selection list CSA-ProcessInstance-State) Result\: _processInstanceState -Updated Process Instance State 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.ca27f9e0-bdd7-42fe-a969-5a77252af94a.description=
Useful Op to keep a running results.
Takes a string input (resultText) and appends this to a global context key of "runningResults". As a result, the context key whose name is in the keyName input will be appended with the string from the input resultText.

Input Parameters\:
keyName - name of context key to append to
resultText - string input to append
delimiter - (leave blank for none) the delimiter to put between what is already in keyName before appending resultText

Responses\:
success - assigned the context variable

Returns\:
The the value of the context variable it appended to.

Context\:
runningResults

Scriptlet Example\:
currentResults \= scriptletContext.get("runningResults");

if (currentResults \=\= null) {
   currentResults \= resultText;
} else {
   currentResults +\= resultText;
}


scriptletContext.putGlobal("runningResults", currentResults);
822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.description=Purpose\: This OO flow removes all disks which were created as part of a cluster and shared over multiple servers. Therefor not specific to a server lifecycle but to the undeplpyment of a cluster. Prerequisites\: 1. Decommissioning has started 2. No manual intervention on these disks have taken place Implementation\: The flow starts with the default get user identifier to get the user identifier for the inbound OO user in CSA. Then the flow gets the primary server component ID using the default get artifact details flow and all subscription details as needed. A 3par host is selected with the default flow. The cluster name is retrieved from InfraDB with the following statement\: SELECT VNAME FROM CCLUSTER WHERE CSASUBSCRIPTIONID\='<>' AND TYPE\='CLU' With the cluster name, the flow is now able to select all disks created for this cluster. And add them to a list. The clusters are retrieved by the following statement\: select DISKNAME, LUNWWNAME, DISKID from diskdrive where hostname\='<>' and diskname like '<>%' and status like '00_ACTIVE' The flow checks if the result is null, if it is and there is nothing to remove, the flow completes. When there are disks to remove, the 3par is send a command to unpresent the disk to the hostset with the following command\: removevlun -f <> <> set\:<> After unpresenting, the disk itself is removed on 3par level\: removevv -f <> As a last step for this disk, it is set to decommissioned on the infra DB with the following statement\: update diskdrive set status \='99_DECOMMISSIONED' where diskid \= ‘<>’ This concludes the step for an individual disk. The flow then further loops through all disks known in the InfraDB and removes them. If all are removed, the flow send a successful notification to CSA and resolves in success. 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.dfe7384f-70ee-48c5-b6e7-5c3d3d167143.description=Generic flow to send an e-mail 822a390b-b67f-4cf9-8a84-75cc2366452e.fcf9aa25-e29f-4772-87c9-b5dda4d8ddf3.description=
Runs a SQL query against an Oracle database, using the information in the tnsnames.ora file.  
The first row is returned on the first run of the operation. Subsequent calls with the same information return the other rows.

Inputs\:
    TNSPath -The path to the folder of the TNS file tnsnames.ora. This path must be accessible by the OO RAS service. For example, if the RAS and the Oracle server are installed on the same Windows system, the TNSPath might look like “C\:\app\Administrator\product\11.1.0\db_1\network\admin”. If the RAS and the Oracle server are on different Windows systems, you can copy the tnsnames.ora file  to the RAS system. The TNSPath might look like “C\:\Program Files\Hewlett-Packard\Operations Orchestration\RAS\Java\Default\webapp\conf” or “C\:\Temp” depending on where you place the .ora file. 
    TNSEntry - The entry name in the tnsnames.ora file that contains the connection information. For example, the value for the TNSEntry input is “TestEntry” if the content in the tnsnames.ora file looks like the following\: 

TestEntry \=
  (DESCRIPTION \=
   (ADDRESS \= (PROTOCOL \= TCP)(HOST \= 16.110.111.111)(PORT \= 1521))
   (CONNECT_DATA \=
     (SERVER \= DEDICATED)
     (SERVICE_NAME \= orcl)
   )
 )

    Username - The username to connect to the Oracle database. 
    Password - The password for the Username.
    Command - The command to execute. 
    Delimiter – The delimiter to use between the columns in the returnResult result.
    Key – The key to use to keep multiple query results distinct.
    timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution.
Default values\: 0 

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. Returned the data returned for each row separated by the value you specified in the Delimiter input (for example, “key16|lst|16”).
    columnNames - The names of the columns returned, separated by the value you specified in the Delimiter input (for example, “MYKEY|NAME|ID”).
    rowsLeft - The number of rows remaining that match the query. 

Responses\:
    more items - More rows are available for retrieval.
    no more items - No more rows are available.
    failure - There was an error executing the command.

Notes\:
1. This operation only supports Oracle. 
2. This operation can only execute the "SELECT" statement. For statements that modify the database, use the TNS Names SQL Command operation.
flow.name: pc_delete_shared_disks

staticBinding.value: SELECT VNAME FROM CCLUSTER WHERE CSASUBSCRIPTIONID='${SVC_SUBSCRIPTION_ID}' AND TYPE='CLU'
update diskdrive set status ='99_DECOMMISSIONED' where diskid = '${diskID}'
select DISKNAME, LUNWWNAME, DISKID from diskdrive where hostname='${server.hostname}' and diskname like '${clusterName}%' and status like '00_ACTIVE'
